metadata.title: A Robot’s Journey. How the world looks to a delivery robot | by Sten Sootla | Towards Data Science

all_paragraphs: It’s fun to imagine, to try to look at the world through the eyes of another. To ponder what it feels like to be an animal.

Our turtle ran away. Was he unhappy? Our parrot flew headfirst into a wall. Was she depressed? Our cat used to shit on my bed. Did she hate me? Our dog’s balls were cut off. Was he mad? These are the kinds of things that kept me up at night throughout my childhood, for there were no answers.

Nowadays, I have it easier. Instead of the unpredictable chunks of flesh shaped by evolution, I’m surrounded with mechanical man-made creatures behaving in accordance with formal logic. Creatures whose every act of defiance can be traced back through computer code to its root cause and weeded out.

My job as an engineer is precisely that — to put myself in the shoes of a six-wheeled autonomous delivery robot and tame it. These are the questions that keep me up at night in my adulthood, for I’m perennially working on the answers:
The eyes of a robot, like these of people, come in pairs. Two eyes make it easy to gauge the distance to the objects in the world, to see things in three dimensions.

As the light bounces off of objects and enters our eye — or camera, in the case of the robot — an image is created on our retina. Since our eyes are in different positions on our head, the images they capture are slightly different as well. If we overlaid them on top of each other, we’d see that the positions of the corresponding objects on the images wouldn’t exactly match. Everything would be horizontally shifted, appearing a little bit more to the left on the right image, and vice versa.

The twist: the more an object shifts from one image to the other, the closer it is to us. The less it shifts, the farther it is. It’s an astonishing mathematical fact. To understand how many meters an object is away from us in the real world, we merely have to measure the millimeters it has moved between the images.

The problem: matching the objects. To calculate how much an object has shifted between the two images, we must first identify it on both of them. Humans are exceptionally good at this, we do it subconsciously. Robots are exceptionally bad at this — thank God, for it keeps me employed.

The robot is a pedestrian — it drives on sidewalks. And like pedestrians, it’s pestered by road crossings. Its idyllic, carefree stroll is promptly replaced by terror, for there is now a stream of vicious two-ton savages it has to maneuver through. Hurry, and you might be flattened in cold blood. Stall, and you might be dismantled for serving cold food.

An enormous task requires enormous intelligence. The robot’s brain-for-vehicles is a deep stack of layers, each a sheet of millions of artificial neurons. The different layers are akin to specialized workers at a conveyor belt, with succeeding layers building on top of the results of the preceding.

An image — a soup of raw, indiscernible pixels for the robot — comes in from the camera. The bottommost layer recognizes groups of pixels that represent edges. The next sheet of neurons recognizes shapes — circles, rectangles, and triangles — built up from the edges. The third layer puts together these geometric shapes to discerns entire objects: wheels, doors, windows, and license plates. The topmost layer assembles the various car parts to recognize complete vehicles.

It’s this single-purpose brain, devoted solely to preventing the robot from becoming a roadkill, that allows for safe road crossings. Compare that to animals, who dedicate only a tiny fraction of their mental capacity to recognizing cars. That’s why it’s squirrels you see dead all over the place, not robots.
The only thing worse than a late delivery is a lost delivery. To avoid such a host of misery, robots have taken a page from the playbook of London’s cab drivers.

To get their license, the budding cabbies need to ace the world’s hardest geography test — a demanding test of the tens of thousands of streets, landmarks, and tourist destinations of London. In preparation for the exam, the candidates drive through the city hundreds of times, for nearly half a decade, trying to etch the tangled arteries of London into their brain.

Robots, likewise, need to practice. Before they’re given free rein of the city, they’re driven through it manually, accompanied by a human overseer. But unlike the black cabbie hopefuls, robots need hand-holding only once.

If computers are good at anything, it’s memorization. During their singular mapping run, the robot takes pictures, many times a second, along the entire route. Next, it extracts relevant objects — items as granular as the individual wooden boards of a park bench or bricks of a chimney — from the images. Finally, time-intensive algorithms figure out the real-world coordinates of all these objects, which are then stored in an enormous data center that makes up the robot’s immensely detailed memory.

Afterward, whenever a now-autonomous robot is uncertain of its location, it searches this database for the closest match to its current surroundings. Like the London cab drivers, their artificial counterparts map the local scene — how the objects they see relate to each other — with the global knowledge stored in their memory — how these objects relate to the city at large. Robots just build this understanding in days, not years.
Soon enough, you’ll see one of these delivery robots toiling away in your own neighborhood. Usually, you’ll see them at their best, efficient and effective.

Occasionally, you’ll also see them at their worst. Perhaps confused on a sidewalk. Or petrified to cross a car road. Forgive them their clumsiness. As Theodore Roosevelt put it: “The only man who never makes a mistake is the man who never does anything.” Robots do a lot. They deliver.

Building robots by day, thinking hard how not to become one myself by night.
